title: 106_s14
content: The "Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999" is a modification to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically focusing on Education Individual Retirement Accounts. The "Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999" amends Section 530(b)(2) to include tax-free expenditures for elementary and secondary school expenses as qualified education expenses. This encompasses tuition credits and certificates. The "Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999" expands qualified education expenses to include tax-free expenditures for elementary and secondary school expenses such as tuition, fees, academic tutoring, special needs services, books, supplies, and computer equipment. The "Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999" allows tax-free expenditures for elementary and secondary school expenses, including tuition, fees, academic tutoring, special needs services, books, supplies, and computer equipment. It also covers expenses for room and board, uniforms, transportation, and supplementary items and services required by public, private, or religious schools. Additionally, homeschooling expenses are included in the definition of qualified education expenses. The "Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999" allows tax-free expenditures for elementary and secondary school expenses, including tuition, fees, academic tutoring, special needs services, books, supplies, and computer equipment. It also covers expenses for room and board, uniforms, transportation, and supplementary items and services required by public, private, or religious schools, as well as homeschooling if state or local laws are met. The term "school" refers to any institution providing kindergarten through grade 12 education. Special rules apply for elementary and secondary education expenses under Section 530(d)(2). The Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999 allows tax-free expenditures for elementary and secondary education expenses, including tuition, fees, tutoring, special needs services, books, supplies, and computer equipment. Qualified expenses for education individual retirement accounts are limited to contributions made between December 31, 1998, and January 1, 2003, along with earnings on those contributions. Trustee of the account must maintain separate accounts for contributions and earnings. The Education Savings Account and School Excellence Act of 1999 allows tax-free expenditures for elementary and secondary education expenses. Contributions and earnings are allocated for qualified expenses, with excess distributions going towards non-qualified expenses. Amendments are made to section 530 to adjust contribution limits. Amendments to section 530 include adjusting contribution limits for education individual retirement accounts. The contribution limit is now defined as $500 ($2,000 for years between 1998 and 2003). Age limitations for children with special needs are waived under this section. The amendments to section 530 include waiving age limitations for designated beneficiaries with special needs. Corporations are now permitted to contribute to accounts, with adjusted maximum contribution amounts for individual contributors. These changes will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1998.
